page.title: 06THE WEY AND ARUN CANAL
page.content: The river Arun is navigable for small craft only up to Pallingham. In the Napoleonic Wars a means was sought for transporting goods from London to Portsmouth without having to sail round an enemy infested coast. The rivers Wey and Arun were linked by a canal, though this did not open until after the wars in the 1820s. It operated only for about 60 years and became uneconomic with the arrival of the railways. The bed of the canal is now overgrown, treelined and mostly dry. In the NW corner of our block it runs close to the loop of the Arun. The Wey and Arun Canal Trust is a voluntary society which hopes to restore the canal. Some of the farmers whose land adjoins the canal support the project but others have formed the Old Canal Owners Assn. to oppose it.
